api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title> <jats:p> The gene ( <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> ) encoding the aerobic C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylate transporter (DctA) of <jats:italic>Escherichia coli</jats:italic> was previously mapped to the 79-min region of the linkage map. The nucleotide sequence of this region reveals two candidates for the <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> gene: <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> at 79.3 min and the <jats:italic>o157a-o424-o328</jats:italic> (or <jats:italic>orfQMP</jats:italic> ) operon at 79.9 min. The <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> gene encodes a homologue of the <jats:italic>Sinorhizobium meliloti</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Rhizobium leguminosarum</jats:italic> H <jats:sup>+</jats:sup> /C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylate symporter, DctA, whereas the <jats:italic>orfQMP</jats:italic> operon encodes homologues of the aerobic periplasmic-binding protein- dependent C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylate transport system (DctQ, DctM, and DctP) of <jats:italic>Rhodobacter capsulatus</jats:italic> . To determine which, if either, of these loci specify the <jats:italic>E. coli</jats:italic> DctA system, the chromosomal <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>orfM</jats:italic> genes were inactivated by inserting Sp <jats:sup>r</jats:sup> or Ap <jats:sup>r</jats:sup> cassettes, respectively. The resulting <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> mutant was unable to grow aerobically with fumarate or malate as the sole carbon source and grew poorly with succinate. Furthermore, fumarate uptake was abolished in the <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> mutant and succinate transport was âˆ¼10-fold lower than that of the wild type. The growth and fumarate transport deficiencies of the <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> mutant were complemented by transformation with an <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> -containing plasmid. No growth defect was found for the <jats:italic>orfM</jats:italic> mutant. In combination, the above findings confirm that <jats:italic>f428</jats:italic> corresponds to the <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> gene and indicate that the <jats:italic>orfQMP</jats:italic> products play no role in C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylate transport. Regulation studies with a <jats:italic>dctA-lacZ</jats:italic> ( <jats:italic>f428-lacZ</jats:italic> ) transcriptional fusion showed that <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> is subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein (CRP)-dependent catabolite repression and ArcA-mediated anaerobic repression and is weakly induced by the DcuS-DcuR system in response to C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylates and citrate. Interestingly, in a <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> mutant, expression of <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> is constitutive with respect to C <jats:sub>4</jats:sub> -dicarboxylate induction, suggesting that DctA regulates its own synthesis. Northern blot analysis revealed a single, monocistronic <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> transcript and confirmed that <jats:italic>dctA</jats:italic> is subject to regulation by catabolite repression and CRP. Reverse transcriptase-mediated primer extension indicated a single transcriptional start site centered 81 bp downstream of a strongly predicted CRP-binding site. </jats:p>

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Inactivation and Regulation of the Aerobic C 4 -Dicarboxylate Transport ( dctA ) Gene of Escherichia coli

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: The gene (dctA) encoding the aerobic C4-dicarboxylate transporter (DctA) of Escherichia coli was previously mapped to the 79-min region of the linkage map. The nucleotide sequence of this region reveals two candidates for the dctA gene: f428 at 79.3 min and the o157a-o424-o328 (or orfQMP) operon at 79.9 min. The f428 gene encodes a homologue of the Sinorhizobium meliloti and Rhizobium leguminosarum H+/C4n-dicarboxylate symporter, DctA, whereas the orfQMP operon encodes homologues of the aerobic periplasmic- binding protein-dependent C4-dicarboxylate transport system (DctQ, DctM, and DctP) of Rhodobacter capsulatus. To determine which, if either, of these loci specify the E. coli DctA system, the chromosomal f428 and orfM genes were inactivated by inserting Sp(r) or Ap(r) cassettes, respectively. The resulting f428 mutant was unable to grow aerobically with fumarate or malate as the sole carbon source and grew poorly with succinate. Furthermore, fumarate uptake was abolished in the f428 mutant and succinate transport was ~10-fold lower than that of the wild type. The growth and fumarate transport deficiencies of the f428 mutant were complemented by transformation with an f428-containing plasmid. No growth defect was found for the orfM mutant. In combination, the above findings confirm that f428 corresponds to the dctA gene and indicate that the orfQMP products play no role in C4-dicarboxylate transport. Regulation studies with a dctA-lacZ (f428-lacZ) transcriptional fusion showed that dctA is subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein (CRP)- dependent catabolite repression and ArcA-mediated anaerobic repression and is weakly induced by the DcuS-DcuR system in response to C4-dicarboxylates and citrate. Interestingly, in a dctA mutant, expression of dctA is constitutive with respect to C4-dicarboxylate induction, suggesting that DctA regulates its own synthesis. Northern blot analysis revealed a single, monocistronic dctA transcript and confirmed that dctA is subject to regulation by catabolite repression and CRP. Reverse transcriptase-mediated primer extension indicated a single transcriptional start site centered 81 bp downstream of a strongly predicted CRP-binding site.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Inactivation and regulation of the aerobic C<inf>4</inf>-dicarboxylate transport (dctA) gene of Escherichia coli

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: The gene (dctA) encoding the aerobic C(4)-dicarboxylate transporter (DctA) of Escherichia coli was previously mapped to the 79-min region of the linkage map. The nucleotide sequence of this region reveals two candidates for the dctA gene: f428 at 79.3 min and the o157a-o424-o328 (or orfQMP) operon at 79.9 min. The f428 gene encodes a homologue of the Sinorhizobium meliloti and Rhizobium leguminosarum H(+)/C(4)-dicarboxylate symporter, DctA, whereas the orfQMP operon encodes homologues of the aerobic periplasmic-binding protein- dependent C(4)-dicarboxylate transport system (DctQ, DctM, and DctP) of Rhodobacter capsulatus. To determine which, if either, of these loci specify the E. coli DctA system, the chromosomal f428 and orfM genes were inactivated by inserting Sp(r) or Ap(r) cassettes, respectively. The resulting f428 mutant was unable to grow aerobically with fumarate or malate as the sole carbon source and grew poorly with succinate. Furthermore, fumarate uptake was abolished in the f428 mutant and succinate transport was approximately 10-fold lower than that of the wild type. The growth and fumarate transport deficiencies of the f428 mutant were complemented by transformation with an f428-containing plasmid. No growth defect was found for the orfM mutant. In combination, the above findings confirm that f428 corresponds to the dctA gene and indicate that the orfQMP products play no role in C(4)-dicarboxylate transport. Regulation studies with a dctA-lacZ (f428-lacZ) transcriptional fusion showed that dctA is subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein (CRP)-dependent catabolite repression and ArcA-mediated anaerobic repression and is weakly induced by the DcuS-DcuR system in response to C(4)-dicarboxylates and citrate. Interestingly, in a dctA mutant, expression of dctA is constitutive with respect to C(4)-dicarboxylate induction, suggesting that DctA regulates its own synthesis. Northern blot analysis revealed a single, monocistronic dctA transcript and confirmed that dctA is subject to regulation by catabolite repression and CRP. Reverse transcriptase-mediated primer extension indicated a single transcriptional start site centered 81 bp downstream of a strongly predicted CRP-binding site.

api:address.api:line: Krebs Institute for Biomolecular Research, Department of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, University of Sheffield, Sheffield S10 2TN, United Kingdom.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Inactivation and regulation of the aerobic C(4)-dicarboxylate transport (dctA) gene of Escherichia coli.

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: The gene (dctA) encoding the aerobic C(4)-dicarboxylate transporter (DctA) of Escherichia coli was previously mapped to the 79-min region of the linkage map. The nucleotide sequence of this region reveals two candidates for the dctA gene: f428 at 79.3 min and the o157a-o424-o328 (or orfQMP) operon at 79.9 min. The f428 gene encodes a homologue of the Sinorhizobium meliloti and Rhizobium leguminosarum H(+)/C(4)-dicarboxylate symporter, DctA, whereas the orfQMP operon encodes homologues of the aerobic periplasmic-binding protein- dependent C(4)-dicarboxylate transport system (DctQ, DctM, and DctP) of Rhodobacter capsulatus. To determine which, if either, of these loci specify the E. coli DctA system, the chromosomal f428 and orfM genes were inactivated by inserting Sp(r) or Ap(r) cassettes, respectively. The resulting f428 mutant was unable to grow aerobically with fumarate or malate as the sole carbon source and grew poorly with succinate. The growth and fumarate transport deficiencies of the f428 mutant were complemented by transformation with an f428-containing plasmid. No growth defect was found for the orfM mutant. In combination, the above findings confirm that f428 corresponds to the dctA gene and indicate that the orfQMP products play no role in C(4)-dicarboxylate transport. Regulation studies with a dctA-lacZ (f428-lacZ) transcriptional fusion showed that dctA is subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein (CRP)-dependent catabolite repression and ArcA-mediated anaerobic repression and is weakly induced by the DcuS-DcuR system in response to C(4)-dicarboxylates and citrate. Interestingly, in a dctA mutant, expression of dctA is constitutive with respect to C(4)-dicarboxylate induction, suggesting that DctA regulates its own synthesis. Northern blot analysis revealed a single, monocistronic dctA transcript and confirmed that dctA is subject to regulation by catabolite repression and CRP. Reverse transcriptase-mediated primer extension indicated a single transcriptional start site centered 81 bp downstream of a strongly predicted CRP-binding site.
